Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Vegetation And Ecosystem Impacts On Permafrost Vulnerability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical

Realistic representations of heat exchange in permafrost ecosystems are necessary for accurate predictive understanding of the permafrost carbon feedback under future climate scenarios. This project will provide a quantitative pan-arctic assessment of the effects of vegetation and landscape characteristics on permafrost thermal regimes. By working across ecosystems, landscape characteristics, and regions, the research will identify broad trends, and intensive energy balance sites will provide a mechanistic study of ecosystem impacts on permafrost response to climate change. The impacts of this study will be enhanced through integration of research results into regional and site-specific permafrost models and synthesis activities that will examine ecosystem impacts on energy balance and permafrost vulnerability to climate change.

This work will have broad impacts on the scientific community and general public because it brings together important issues in the global environment and raises awareness of the connection between ecosystem dynamics and permafrost thaw. The proposed project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate students through collaboration between the researchers and an NSF funded field research experience for undergraduates. The researchers will mentor several students as part of this proposed work and will also teach two arctic system science courses at a predominantly undergraduate institution. This project will enhance scientific understanding through continued work with education centers, local communities and, in particular, with teachers and outreach coordinators.

Technical

Significant declines in permafrost distribution are expected as the climate warms, but large uncertainties remain in determining the fate of permafrost under future climate scenarios. These uncertainties are driven, in large part, by vegetation and ecosystem properties that modulate the effect of climate on permafrost temperatures. Long-term monitoring of permafrost temperatures demonstrates the importance of these local conditions, yet there has been no pan-arctic effort to measure ecological and landscape variables in concert with permafrost temperature monitoring. This project will use a combination of field and remotely-sensed data to address the question of how vegetation and landscape factors modulate permafrost temperature response to climate change. To address this question the researchers will couple an extensive pan-arctic assessment of vegetation-permafrost dynamics with an intensive study of shrub and tree canopy cover effects on ecosystem energy balance. The first component of this research will be conducted at long-term permafrost temperature monitoring sites in Siberia and Alaska, and the second component, the vegetation-energy balance sites that will be established as part of this proposal, will be conducted at a shrub-tree canopy cover gradient in Siberia, where most permafrost regions are located. These intensively studied energy balance sites will provide an improved mechanistic understanding of the effects of ecosystem components, and interactions among these components, on ecosystem energy balance and permafrost vulnerability to climate change. This mechanistic knowledge will, in turn, support interpretation of broad patterns observed through a pan-arctic sampling of the permafrost temperature monitoring sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We extended observation network of the “Thermal Ste of Permafrost” project (NSF award 1304271). Two new boreholes and three near-surface ground temperature observation sites were established in Alaska and 4 boreholes plus 8 near- surface observation points - in Siberia. We also extended observation program at three existing sites in Alaska. Conducted ecological survey at the 17 Alaskan and 14 Siberian sites also provides essential background information for interpretation of data of ground temperature monitoring. At the field sites had been studied, annual average ground surface temperatures were 1.5 to 9°C warmer than air temperatures, and this difference was primarily driven by the insulating impact of snow during the winter season.  In boreal forests, the cooling effect of vegetation during the growing season resulted in  ~-5°C lower ground temperature compared to air temperature, which offset some of the soil warming effects of snow. As canopy cover increased, the difference between winter air and ground temperature decreased due to snow trapping and reduction of the insulating snow layer. In a pan-arctic synthesis, we found that decoupling between summer air and soil temperatures was more variable in boreal ecosystems than tundra ecosystems.Boreal ecosystems had lower winter n-factors (ratio of soil to air temperature) than tundra ecosystems, and summer n-factors were more variable than winter n-factors due to variation in vegetation and ecosystem characteristics. Across the latitudinal transect of 17 sites in Alaska that spanned discontinuous to continuous permafrost zones, there was no detectable latitudinal trend in active layer depth across sites, nor were there significant differences between tundra and boreal sites. Surprisingly, there was a slight positive trend between latitude and active layer depth in the tundra sites. Patterns of ground thaw across sites suggest that vegetation composition and ecosystem characteristics, including ground saturation and organic layer depth, were key modulators of ground thermal dynamics. Organic layer depth, which is important for its insulative properties, was negatively related to latitude across the Alaska sampling sites (R2 = 0.47). High organic matter content of active layer soil was asscoiated with lower thermal conductivity in both organic and mineral layers. Thaw depth heterogeneity within sites was signficiantly related to measures of vegetation cover, specifically Eriophorum vaginatum. In a synthesis of data from the pan-Arctic region, we found that annual soil thermal regimes varied by plant functional types. Tundra ecosystems dominated by vegetation with tall statured canopies tended to have warmer soil temperatures than sites dominated by short statured vegetation. In boreal forests, soil temperatures were highly variable and decoupled from air temperature.Comparison of the shortwave and photosynthetically active radiation balance at the Smith Lake, AK sites showed that coniferous and deciduous forests with similar canopy coverage provided equal shading during the summer, but more direct solar radiation reached the ground surface in broadleaf forests in the spring and fall. At the same time, the deciduous tree canopy adsorbed more photosynthetically active radiation than spruce canopiesAt high- and low-density larch forests in Cherskiy we observe substantial differences in ecosystem energy partitioning. Surface energy dynamics and ground heat flux varied substantially between high- and low-density larch forests. During snowmelt, dense forests shade the ground, but also enhance emission of longwave radiation. Both of these processes affect snow melt rates, but longwave enhancement is not incorporated in current climate models. During the growing season longwave enhancement increases soil heat fluxes, particularly at night, partially offsetting the effects of canopy shading on ground heat fluxes. Ground heat fluxes during the growing season were generally lower in the denser forest, and differences in ground heat flux tended to correspond to differences in soil temperature and permafrost thaw depth. However, canopy effects on ground heat flux were ameliorated by high soil moisture. These results show that canopy influences on soil thermal dynamics can be modulated by ecological and micrometeorological factors.Extremely high snow accumulation in North-Eastern Siberia and Alaska during the winter seasons of 2017-18combined with sustainable rising of air temperature of winter seasons led to significant increases in the ground warming in these regions. The magnitude of permafrost warming was highest within the wetter environment of floodplain and at the sites with thin organic layer due to amplified insulative effects of snow due to 'trapping' greater flux of latent heat released in wetter areas, while the hilltops within the tundra biome or areas with thick organic horizon in the boreal forest zone showed the rates of permafrost temperature increase lower than air warming.
